where E$_0$ and $\omega$ are the initial energy of target ion and
the oscillating frequency. The m$_f$ and m$_f$ correspond to the
mass of frozen and target ion. The $\tau_{cooling}$ is with strong
dependence on the initial energy. The statistics of $\tau_{cooling}$
from 36 numbers of evens is shown in Fig. \ref{ionchains}. Recording
the time from heating oven to $^{27}$Al$^+$ crystal and then
subtracting the time of loading hot $^{27}$Al$^+$, the cooling time
was obtained. Mostly, the cooling time was about 330s corresponding
to the initial energy was 0.63eV according to Fig. \ref{statics}
which was lower than that of $^{27}$Al$^+$ generated by laser
ablation (600s)\cite{Guggemos15}. Furthermore, the target ion with
high initial energy may kick out the frozen ion. In our experiments,
it is 80\% probability to loading single $^{27}$Al$^+$.

\begin{figure}
\resizebox{0.5\textwidth}{!}{\includegraphics {statics.pdf}}
\caption{Distribution of cooling times, measured by recording the
time it takes a laser cooled $^{40}$Ca$^+$ ion to crystallize a hot
$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion. The histogram shows that the cooling may vary by
an orer of magnitude}
\label{statics}
\end{figure}

The dark ions might be some ions other than $^{27}$Al$^+$ because
$^{40}$Ca$^+$ and $^{27}$Al$^+$ can react with background gas to
molecular ions, such as CaH$^+$,
AlH$^+$\cite{Macalpine59,Khanyile15} and so on. In addition, there
are no differences in the CCD image. Thus the mass of dark ions
should be measured to know the ions species. To diagnose of the dark
ions, we measured the frequency of vibrational modes of two mixed
ion species. The mode frequency of the ions along axial direction
depends on the mass as well as the arrangement of the ions, and can

prevtext:
\title{Rapid and effective synthesis of $^{40}$Ca$^+$-$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion pair towards quantum logic optical clock}



\author{Junjuan Shang\inst{1}\inst{2}\inst{3}
\and Kaifeng Cui\inst{1}\inst{2}\inst{3} \and Jian
Cao\inst{1}\inst{2} \and Shaomao Wang\inst{1} \inst{2}\inst{3} \and
Hualin Shu\inst{1}\inst{2} \and Xueren Huang\inst{1}\inst{2}

\thanks{hxueren@wipm.ac.cn}
}                     

\institute{State Key Laboratory of Magnetic Resonance and Atomic and
Molecular Physics, Wuhan Institute of Physics and Mathematics,
Chinese Academy of Sciences,Wuhan 430071
 \and Key Laboratory of Atom Frequency Standards, Wuhan Institute of Physics and Mathematics
 \and University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China}

\date{Received: date / Revised version: date}


\maketitle

\begin{abstract}
\begin{sloppypar}
High precision atomic clocks have been applied not only to very
important technological problems such as synchronization and global
navigation systems, but to the fundament precision measurement
physics. Single $^{27}$Al$^+$ is one of the most attractions of
selection system due to its very low blackbody radiation effect
which dominates frequency shifts in other optical clock systems. Up
to now, the $^{27}$Al$^+$ still could not be laser-cooled directly
by reason that the absence of 167nm laser. Sympathetic cooling is a
viable method to solve this problem. In this work, we used a single
laser cooled $^{40}$Ca$^+$ to sympathetically cool one $^{27}$Al$^+$
in linear Paul trap. Comparing to laser ablation method we got a
much lower initial energy (0.63eV) atoms sprayed from a home-made
atom oven, which would make loading aluminum ion more efficient and
the sympathetic cooling much easier. The probability of loading
single $^{27}$Al$^+$ is about 80\%. By precisely measuring the
secular frequency of the ion pair,finally the dark ion species,
$^{27}$Al$^+$, was proved, which could be used to quantum logic
optical frequency standard.
\end{sloppypar}
\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}
\label{intro}

Single atomic ions trapped in an RF Paul
trap\cite{Chou03,Dube15,Godun14,Huang12,Rosenband08} and atomic
ensemble trapped in an optical
lattice\cite{Nicholson15,Hinkley13,McFerran14} are the most two
primary approaches of optical clock experiments. It has been
demonstrated that optical clock frequency measurement had a
fractional uncertainty of 10$^{-18}$ in systems based on
$^{27}$Al$^+$, $^{171}$Yb$^+$, $^{88}$Sr and $^{171}$Yb atoms
respectively.The $^{27}$Al$^+$ clock based on the
$^1$S$_0$-$^3$P$_0$ transition is stable enough as a reference for
an optical clock \cite{Dehmelt82, Yu92}. The natural linewidth of
$^3$P$_0$ state is 8mHz and the measured transition frequency is
1121 015 393 207 851(6) Hz \cite{Rosenband07}, which means
$^{27}$Al$^+$ has a higher stability at the same feedback velocity
compared to other ions, such as $^{40}$Ca$^+$,$^{171}$Yb$^+$ and so
on. Both the $^1$S$_0$ and $^3$P$_0$ energy levels exhibit only a
weak dependence on the magnetic fields for the Zeeman effect with
angular momentum J=0\cite{Hume10}. As well as it is insensitive to
electric field gradients. Moreover, blackbody radiation shift of
this transition is 8(3)E-18 at room temperature\cite{Rosenband06}.
However, since it is not easy to acquire the direct cooling laser
(167nm), $^{27}$Al$^+$ is performed sympathetic cooling with a
simultaneously trapped ion and readout spectrum with quantum logic
spectrum (QLS)\cite{Rosenband07,Schmidt05}. $^{40}$Ca$^+$ is one of
the popular ion species in optical standard and quantum information
processing (QIP). The lasers applied to $^{40}$Ca$^+$ can be
acquired from external cavity diode laser, which is simpler and
stability. We choose $^{40}$Ca$^+$ as our frozen species.

Sympathetic cooling system includes target and frozen species which
are interacting with each other. The temperatures of these two
species are very low because frozen species can be laser cooled to
low temperature and target species interact or collide with frozen
species to transfer energy with them. Effectiveness of sympathetic
cooling is with strong dependence on the initial
energy\cite{Guggemos15}. sympathetic cooling is one significant
technique in quantum information processing (QIP)\cite{Rohde01},
cold molecules\cite{Kimura11}, optical frequency
standard\cite{Chou03,Hayasaka12} and chemical reactions at very low
temperatures[19].

Here, using a new design of atom oven could generate low velocity,
the $^{40}$Ca$^+$ -$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion pair was synthesized rapidly
and effectively. The mean time of sympathetic cooling by
$^{40}$Ca$^+$ was about 330s, as the low initial energy made it easy
to be trapped and cooled. The secular motion frequency ratio of
$^{40}$Ca$^+$ -$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion pair and $^{40}$Ca$^+$ has been
measured in our trap, which fitted well with theoretical
calculation.

\section{Experimental apparatus}
\label{sec:2} The experiment setup is shown in Fig.\ref{setup2}. A
linear Paul trap was made of stainless steel with a dimension of
2r$_0$=1.6mm and 2z$_0$=5mm to confine ions. A radiofrequency (RF)
voltage at the frequency 17.128 MHz was applied to bladelike
electrodes A and the other pair bladelike electrodes B were RF
grounded. The endcap electrodes were with DC voltage
(Fig.\ref{setup2}(b)). $^{40}$Ca oven and $^{27}$Al oven were placed
under the electric shield stage with an angle of 25$^o$ angle to
prevent calcium or aluminum atom from adhering to the electrodes
which may cause the electric field of ion trap change. The ion trap
was enclosed in a UHV chamber (3E-8Pa) evacuated by a 75L/s ion pump
(Fig.\ref{setup2}(a)). The external-cavity diode laser of 423nm and
LED of 395nm were used to photo-ionization of $^{40}$Ca, moreover
the 394nm laser served as $^{27}$Al photo-ionization laser. The
$^{40}$Ca$^+$ was Doppler cooled by 397nm and 866nm lasers. The
$^{40}$Ca$^+$ fluorescence was detected by PMT and EMCCD.
Fig.\ref{setups2}(c) shows the energy level of $^{27}$Al.

\begin{figure}
\resizebox{0.5\textwidth}{!}{\includegraphics {setup2.pdf}}
\caption{(a) and (b) is Experimental setup and ion trap. (c) and (d)
is the Aluminum atom energy and Aluminum oven setup.}
\label{setups}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}
\begin{center}
\resizebox{0.45\textwidth}{!}{\includegraphics {ovens.pdf}}
\end{center}
\caption{The relation of the temperature of oven with (a) time at 4A
current and (b) heating current.}
\label{ovens}
\end{figure}

We designed 20mm length stainless steel tube oven with diameter
1.5mm, and thickness 0.1mm to generate $^{40}$Ca and $^{27}$Al
atoms. In experiment only $^{40}$Ca atom signal was detected. The
relation between temperature and the current applied to oven have
been measured with thermos couple in vacuum chamber (0.1Pa). The
temperature of stainless steel tube oven is only 600$^{\circ}$C at
11A current. Since the saturated vapor pressure of $^{27}$Al is very
low, the $^{27}$Al must be heated high than 700$^{\circ}$C the atom
signal could be detected. For above reason a ceramics tube oven was
designed to supersede the traditional stainless oven. The oven
included two ceramic tubes and tungsten wire. One ceramics tube was
spiral winded with tungsten wire. And both embedded in another
ceramics tube(Fig. \ref{setups}(b)). The temperature of new oven was
also measured and the result was displayed in Fig. \ref{ovens}.
Temperature of ceramics oven is obvious high compared to stainless
steel oven at the same current and the time of heating to
700$^{\circ}$C is about 2 minutes.
\section{Experimental results}
\label{sec:3}

$^{40}$Ca$^+$($^{27}$Al$^+$) was generated by photo ionization
neutral calcium (aluminum) atom beam, which could reduce the
impaction of stray electric field. The specific number of ions were
obtained by controlling the time of heating calcium (aluminum) oven
at about 300$^{\circ}$C(700$^{\circ}$C). After several minutes later
the ions was loaded in the ion trap one by one. It was necessary to
block the photo-ionization laser after loading ions because the oven
was still with high temperature after shutting down the current.

After $^{40}$Ca$^+$ was trapped in the ion trap, the current was
applied to the aluminum oven and illuminated 394nm laser with
500$\mu$W power to insert $^{27}$Al$^+$ to the $^{40}$Ca$^+$ chain.
The RF power and endcap voltage must be reduced because the
temperature of ions was high at the same time when $^{27}$Al$^+$
generated. Several minutes later the position of $^{40}$Ca$^+$ in
the CCD shifted which indicated that dark ion was trapped. The
number of dark ions could be diagnosed by ions distance because the
distances of neighboring ions is related to the number of ions, it
has no relation with ion species as long as they are singly charged.
And the ions hopped back and forth between different axial positions
when low DC voltages applied to the endcaps. The different positions
of $^{40}$Ca$^+$ were imaged with CCD, as shown in Fig.
\ref{ionchains}. By adding several of such images together, it could
be showing the ions at all different positions. And then the dark
ions number is confirmed.

\begin{figure}
\begin{center}
\resizebox{0.5\textwidth}{!}{\includegraphics {ionchains.pdf}}
\end{center}
\caption{6 ions of $^{40}$Ca$^+$ and $^{27}$Al$^+$ mixture ion
crystal} \label{ionchains}
\end{figure}

Sympathetic cooling process as a sequence of successive Coulomb
collisions between the particles transfers momentum from the target
ion to the frozen ion held at low temperature by laser cooling. The
time ($\tau_{cooling}$) needed from cooling ion cloud to crystal
state is[15]:

nexttext:
where $\omega$ and $\mu$ is the secular motion frequency of single
ion and the mass ratio, respectively. For
$^{40}$Ca$^+$-$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion pair the common frequencies are
calculated as 1.083 relative to that of two $^{40}$Ca$^+$
center-of-mass mode. The secular motion frequency can be measured by
RF resonance\cite{Wineland75} and $^{40}$Ca$^+$ ions secular motion
sideband spectra[23].

\begin{figure}
\resizebox{0.5\textwidth}{!}{\includegraphics {frequences.pdf}}
\caption{Measurement the $\omega_z$ using (a)RF resonance and
(b)secular motion sideband spectrum} \label{frequences}
\end{figure}

The secular motion excitation mass spectrum along z axial can be
measured by applying the characteristic perturbation RF voltages to
one of the endcaps. When the frequency is resonant with the secular
motion frequency, the ion starts to oscillate along the excited
normal mode direction. Then, its amplitude of motion could be
determined by the electric field. And the laser-induced fluorescence
(LIF) counts decreases or increases due to the changing Doppler
width of the cooling transition. The mass spectrum could be measured
precisely using secular motion sideband spectra. The secular motion
sideband spectrum is different when have or not dark ion. Fig.
\ref{frequences} displays the measurement results by above two
methods. Fig. \ref{frequences}(a) shows PMT counts against with the
RF frequency. The blue line gives the motion resonant spectrums of
one $^{40}$Ca$^+$ and the red one is the case of
$^{40}$Ca$^+$-$^{27}$Al$^+$ pair. The $\omega_z$ are 535 kHz and 577
kHz respectively. And Fig. \ref{frequences}(b) is the carrier and
secular sideband spectrum. The secular sideband spectrum of
$^{40}$Ca$^+$-$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion pair was shifted about 40 kHz
comparing with single $^{40}$Ca$^+$. We could get the ratio of
secular motion frequency 1.078 $\pm$0.012 and 1.086$\pm$0.02 which
fits well with theoretical calculation. That meant the ion pair
obtained was $^{40}$Ca$^+$-$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion pair.

\section{Conclusions}
\label{sec:4}

In this report, $^{40}$Ca$^+$-$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion pair was synthesized
rapidly and effectively by using a novel oven heating. The average
time of sympathetic cooling was about 330s. In addition, the new
designed oven can also be used to be heat other materials evaporated
under high temperature. The drawback of new design oven is that it
is possible to load more than one $^{27}$Al$^+$ due to unable block
the aluminum atom beam immediately. The dark ion mass was
distinguished by the ion mass spectrum which was measured and
analyzed by using RF resonance and secular motion sideband spectra.
The rapid and effective synthesis of $^{40}$Ca$^+$-$^{27}$Al$^+$ ion
pair is significance and necessary on progress of $^{27}$Al$^+$
quantum logic optical clock in the near future.
